text: we are standing in the middle of Times
Square right now at the junction of
broadway and seventh avenue it's
probably New York's most iconic
intersection and as you can see all
around me it is unquestionably one of
the nation's busiest intersections too
busy in fact Mayor Michael R Bloomberg
says and he wants to do something to
calm the traffic here and in herald
square where Macy's is by turning
Broadway from 59th to twenty-third
Street into a much more pedestrian
friendly environment this is not the
first time that the city has tried to do
something about traffic on Broadway and
the inevitable collision that occurs
between pedestrians and vehicles in fact
as long ago as the days just after the
Civil War an iron bridge a pedestrian
bridge was constructed across broadway
at Fulton Street in lower Manhattan
which was then the busiest intersection
in New York unfortunately for the
pedestrians who used that bridge it
obstructed knocks the Hatters a very
influential business of its day and the
bridge lasted only a year since then
planners have tried everything they've
tried elevated tracks over Broadway
subways under Broadway they've dreamed
up pedestrian bridges that would run
from one building to the next
nothing much has come of these measures
and as you can see traffic still is
cacophonous here's something I never
thought I'd be doing sitting at a table
in the middle of Broadway in Times
Square this is exactly the kind of Plaza
that the Bloomberg administration
imagines putting along Broadway and 59th
to twenty-third Street the Bloomberg
administration actually may have caused
to be optimistic these mini plazas have
proved to be very successful even on a

with tables bicycles are going by
pedestrians are taking advantage of the
